title: Mauricio Pochettino is 'finished' if Spurs lose to Watford, says Tony Cascarino
text:
Mauricio Pochettino is under pressure following Tottenham’s 3-0 defeat against Brighton (Picture: EPA)

Mauricio Pochettino will receive his marching orders at Tottenham if he is unable to inspire his side to victory against struggling Watford after the international break, according to Tony Cascarino.

The Argentine has done an exceptional job during his five years in charge of Spurs and steered the club to a first Champions League final in June, but he is under pressure after a disastrous week.

Spurs suffered a humiliating 7-2 home defeat to Bayern Munich in the Champions League on Tuesday and followed that up with a dismal 3-0 loss to Brighton and Hove Albion at the Amex Stadium on Saturday.

Spurs were left stunned by Brighton at the Amex on Saturday (Picture: Getty)

That defeat was Spurs’ 17th this calendar year and Cascarino thinks that an 18th loss against winless Watford will force Daniel Levy into taking drastic action.

‘The signs for Tottenham Hostpur are alarming. The team are getting worse, they are noticeably poorer than two years ago,’ Cascarino said in his column for the Times.

‘Jan Vertonghen, Danny Rose, Toby Alderweireld, Dele Alli – none of them are at the levels they were.

‘Mauricio Pochettino’s record entitles him to a fair crack at turning things around but I am sceptical as to whether he can. If they lose to Watford in their next game after the international break, he is finished.

‘He is under pressure and making poor decisions. Eric Dier clearly was not fit to play on Saturday and Moussa Sissoko was out of position at right-back.’

Speaking after Saturday’s loss, Pochettino insisted that he is unconcerned about the prospect of losing his job, saying: ‘No I am not worried, what worries me is life, not football.

‘Football is a game that sometimes you win, sometimes you lose. The problem for us – it was win, win, win and it was praise for everyone.

Tony Cascarino thinks that Pochettino could be sacked if Spurs lose to Watford (Picture: Getty)

‘Now in the last two games it was a tough situation to accept. But I don’t want to be a philosopher or talk in a way that is not good.’

Spurs are next in action against Watford on October 19 before they face Red Star Belgrade in the Champions League and then Liverpool at Anfield the following weekend.
